@laurenboebert https://twitter.com/jacksonleetx18/status/1614898477657464832 QT @JacksonLeeTX18 Lauren, you would think now that you‚Äôre in the majority, you would actually consider reading the bills you tweet about. Or, maybe even hire someone who could help you. This tweet is inflammatory and fact-less and you know it. https://twitter.com/laurenboebert/status/1614843592454930433
With that being said, I hope we can all now honor Dr. King‚Äôs legacy together.

Or on the other hand, if you desire to defend acts of white supremacy or maybe even be one if your heart desires, that is your choice to make; it‚Äôs protected by the first amendment; and I fully support the protections of the first amendment for every American.
Now let me be clear, I‚Äôd be happy to sit down with you to explain the importance of this legislation.

As the nation begins to celebrate Dr. Martin Luther King‚Äôs birthday and my mind is focused on his legacy, you have the audacity to take time out to spout off and misuse your Twitter account to discuss a bill you either you don‚Äôt understand or you haven‚Äôt even read!
Yes, white supremacy should be added to this law. Why? Because as Director Wray testified, it‚Äôs a major domestic terrorist threat.

It is because of these acts, that my bill, the LAWS Act, adds to Section 249(a)(1) of title 18 of the U.S. criminal code after the words ‚Äúrace, color, religion, national origin,‚Äù the language ‚Äúor because a white supremacy based motivation against any person.‚Äù

And then, are you going to deny that the Trump-appointed Director of the FBI testified in March 2021 under oath, under penalty of perjury, that white supremacy was the greatest domestic terror threat facing our country in the Senate Judiciary committee hearing, March 2nd, 2021?

Further, are you going to deny that white supremacy played a role in the Buffalo shooting after the shooter cited ‚Äúreplacement theory‚Äù as his motive to begin a murderous rampage at the closest zip code with the highest black population?
If so, are you going to deny that white supremacy played a role in the Charlottesville attack when Nazi-sympathizers belched ‚ÄúJews will not replace us?‚Äù Who is ‚Äúus?‚Äù
I would hope now that your argument would not shift to ‚Äúwhy is white supremacy being added to this law?‚Äù That would be egregious.
Your argument *assumes* that only white people can hold white supremacist views and that only certain groups of people can perpetrate violence motivated by white supremacy.
So when the article states that ‚Äúonly white people can be charged with‚Äù this crime, that‚Äôs flagrantly false.

For starters, it took me about 32 seconds of reading the article you cited to understand that none of you know what you are talking about. H.R. 61 simply deals with adding white supremacy to a list of reasons to be convicted of a hate crime.

Lauren, you would think now that you‚Äôre in the majority, you would actually consider reading the bills you tweet about. Or, maybe even hire someone who could help you. This tweet is inflammatory and fact-less and you know it. https://twitter.com/laurenboebert/status/1614843592454930433 QT @laurenboebert In case you weren‚Äôt aware of what the Democrats were prioritizing in the 118th Congress, just take a look.

When they‚Äôre not bankrupting our country, they‚Äôre busy making a mockery of the First Amendment. https://national-conservative.com/congressman-introduces-bill-that-criminalizes-criticism-of-a-non-white-person-by-a-white/

Sometimes that‚Äôs how better standards can best be achieved ‚Äî through competitive federalism.  But that doesn‚Äôt work when the federal government occupies the entire field.
Sure, they might be different in some states than others, but would that necessarily be a bad thing?

Standards for food safety, for example, wouldn‚Äôt suddenly disappear if federal regulations in this area were phased out.  A combination of private and state food-safety standards would take the place of federal regulations.

I wonder how any of us can know what it would look like if more activities were regulated by state rather than federal authority. Most of us have never lived in a world without a sprawling federal regulatory system. But does that really mean we couldn‚Äôt live well without it?

Many of those naming federal regulatory agencies they couldn‚Äôt live without ‚Äî for example, the USDA ‚Äîrely on the supposition that states are simply incompetent and couldn‚Äôt do what the federal government can.
Who, then, is harmed by excessive federal regulation? It‚Äôs the American people, and most acutely those of modest means.

These excessive costs might be actually welcomed by large, established firms, which often perversely benefit from onerous regulations, insofar as they tend to exclude would-be competitors who can‚Äôt afford the army of lawyers and compliance specialists necessitated by those regs.
For the wealthy, these costs might be considered just a cost of doing business, or a mild nuisance.
While excessively burdensome, these costs remain largely hidden, as they are difficult to calculate and are rarely discussed‚Äîin the news, the workplace, the classroom, or anywhere else.

While most of us don‚Äôt ever have occasion to see the true cost of these agencies, it affects every one of us‚Äîespecially those of modest means‚Äîbecause the cost is built into everything we buy, and even wages.
I also wonder whether the trillions of dollars Americans spend each year funding and complying with the edicts of these agencies is really justified.

I ask because we‚Äôre often asked to assume that the problems each federal agency was created to address would go ignored or receive inadequate attention but for the federal government‚Äôs involvement. I wonder how often that assumption is warranted.
